thread.section_title: Business Breaking News | Finance & Business News | News.com.au
thread.title: How to pay fewer ATM fees
thread.title_full: How to pay fewer ATM fees

author: ANTHONY KEANE
title: How to pay fewer ATM fees
text:
WITHDRAWALS from ATMs are the most popular way for Australians to grab some cash, and also one of the easiest ways to waste their money.
ATM transactions have almost trebled in the past 15 years, according to the Australian Payments Clearing Association, while Reserve Bank data shows we make about 60 million cash withdrawals a month worth about $11.7 billion.
But you can be slugged $3 or $4 a time for withdrawing your own cash if you’re not careful.
That means two or three withdrawals a week could set you back more than $500 a year.
ASIC senior executive leader of financial literacy Miles Larbey says the easiest way to avoid ATM fees is having a bank account that does not charge you for using them .
People’s Choice spokesman Stuart Symons, with Kate Bagley, says EFTPOS is a good fee-free way to withdraw cash. Source: News Corp Australia
“Many banks, building societies and credit unions offer transaction accounts which allow you to use their ATMs free of charge. Some allow you to use other banks’ ATMs free of charge,” he says.
Planning in advance will reduce the fee impact. Private machines at pubs, cinemas and shops are usually going to charge you more than a bank ATM.
“Visit your bank’s website to find out where the closest ATMs are to your home, workplace and places where you often withdraw money, such as shopping malls,” Larbey says.
People’s Choice Credit Union spokesman Stuart Symons says it’s often cheaper to withdraw cash when making EFTPOS transactions.
“Depending on the retailer, there may be a limit to how much cash you can take out,” he says.
How much is that $50 withdrawal actually costing you? Source: Supplied
Don’t use your credit card for withdrawing cash at an EFTPOS terminal as you are likely to be hit with cash advance fees and high interest rates, Symons says.
If you splash cash regularly and use ATMs too much, schedule larger regular withdrawals to avoid many smaller unplanned ones.
Going digital is another option, Symons says. “Think about whether you really need cash and consider a digital alternative. Contactless payments with your card or mobile phone are perfect for purchases under $100 that you would typically pay cash for, like your morning coffee.”
ASIC’s Larbey says there is no reason to stick with your existing back account if you are unhappy with excessive fees. “It is now easier than ever to switch to an account that has lower fees, easier access, better service or a higher interest rate on savings ,” he says.
